choices.text: Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma
Neovascular Glaucoma
Posner Schlossman Syndrome
Iridocorneal Endothelial Syndrome

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back.  Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascular Glaucoma (NVG)

 

Option B:

 

  • NVG has been called '90' or '100-day glaucoma' in the past due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of CRVO.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Hypoxic retinal tissue produces angiogenic factors (like VEGF) in an attempt to Revascularize Hypoxic Areas.
    • The new vessels encroach on the angle and cause open angle glaucoma. Later when a neovascular membrane is formed, contraction of the membrane causes angle closure glaucoma.
  • Causes:
    • Diabetic Retinopathy (most common)
    • Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma is caused by the physical closure of the anterior chamber angle, leading to increased IOP. It does not typically involve rubeosis iridis.

 

Option C. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome, also known as Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis, this condition typically presents with mild elevation of IOP and not with rubeosis iridis. It's characterized by recurrent attacks of mild inflammation and elevated IOP.

 

Option D. Iridocorneal Endothelial Syndrome rare condition affects the cornea and iris and can lead to secondary glaucoma. It does not typically involve rubeosis iridis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Considering the presence of rubeosis iridis in all four quadrants and the significantly elevated IOP, the diagnosis is Neovascular Glaucoma. This condition is often a consequence of ischemic retinal diseases and presents with new blood vessel formation on the iris and angle, leading to increased intraocular pressure due to impaired aqueous humor drainage.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 371, 372

choices.text: Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma
Uveitis Glaucoma
Pigmentary Glaucoma
Traumatic Glaucoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of painless, gradually progressive reduction of vision of the right eye over several months. IOP was OD: 55mmHg and OS: 19mmHg. Anterior chamber was of normal depth in both eyes. A white flaky disc was seen on the anterior lens capsule after dilatation in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Exfoliation Syndrome (XFS)/ Pseudo-Exfoliation Syndrome are an age-related disease characterized by the production and progressive accumulation of Fibrillar Extracellular Material in Ocular Tissues.
  • Glaucoma in Pseudo-Exfoliation can exhibit as Open-Angle or Angle-Closure Glaucoma.

 

Characteristic features are:

 

  • Lens: The most commonly recognized feature is the 3-ring sign on the anterior lens capsule formed by a central disc, a peripheral ring, and a clear zone, in between.
  • Iris: Fine flaky white material can be seen on the pupillary border of the iris without dilation
  • Pupil: Eyes with XFS often dilate poorly.
  • Zonules and Ciliary Body: Exfoliation material (XFM) may be detected earliest on the ciliary processes and zonules and this creates a tendency for spontaneous subluxation or dislocation of the crystalline lens in advanced cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Uveitis Glaucoma is secondary to uveitis. Signs of active inflammation, such as cells and flare in the anterior chamber or synechiae (adhesion of the iris to the lens or cornea), might be expected.

 

Option C. Pigmentary glaucoma is caused by the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris into aqueous humor. This pigment can clog the trabecular meshwork, increasing intraocular pressure. Typical signs include mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects, dense pigmentation of the trabecular meshwork, and a Krukenberg spindle (a vertical deposition of pigment on the corneal endothelium).

 

Option D. Traumatic glaucoma can occur following an injury to the eye and can present with various signs depending on the mechanism of injury. Features might include irregularities of the pupil, signs of angle recession.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characterized by Flaky, Dandruff-like material depositing on the lens, Pupillary Border, and other structures within the eye. This material can be visualized during an Eye Examination and can lead to Increased Intraocular Pressure.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 250

choices.text: Sturge Weber Syndrome
Neovascular Glaucoma
Neurofibromatosis
Peters Anomaly

questions.text: Raised Episcleral Pressure is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sturge Weber Syndrome

 

Option A:

 

  • Sturge-Weber syndrome (Encephalotrigeminal Angiomatosis)
    • Congenital, Sporadic Phacomatosis.
    • 30% patients develop Glaucoma Ipsilateral to the Facial Hemangioma.
    • Pathogenesis of Glaucoma: uncertain. May be due to trabeculodysgenesis in infants and in older patients, may be due to raised episcleral venous pressure associated with arteriovenous communication in an episcleral hemangioma.
    • Raised episcleral pressure is most often associated with conditions that obstruct the venous outflow from the eye, such as carotid cavernous fistula or orbital tumors.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neovascular Glaucoma: (Pre-Trabecular) Seen in retinal ischemia causing neovascularization over iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis, leading to zip-like adhesions of iris to the cornea at the angle.

 

Option C. Neuro-Fibromatosis: Glaucoma is rare. If develops, is usually unilateral and congenital. Various mechanisms have been identified, including congenital Angle Anomaly.

 

Option D. Peters Anomaly: Glaucoma occurs in about 50% due to associated Angle Anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sturge-Weber Syndrome is associated with raised episcleral pressure related to vascular malformations. It is a cause of congenital glaucoma.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 394

choices.text: Primary Open Angle Glaucoma
Pseudoexfoliation Glaucoma
Phacomorphic Glaucoma
Uveitic Glaucoma

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department complaining of a sudden and painful loss of vision in one eye. Upon carrying out slit lamp examination, findings include 4 + anterior chamber cells, 2+ flare, a fibrinous membrane covering the pupillary area and elevated intraocular pressure. What is the likely diagnosis based on these observations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uveitic Glaucoma

 

Option D: The given clinical scenario is of a patient who has developed glaucoma secondary to an inflammatory condition.

 

UVEITIC GLAUCOMA: Increased IOP secondary to inflammation of uveal tissue (iridocyclitis)

 

Signs of Anterior uveitis:

 

  • Aqueouscells
  • Keratic Precipitates
  • AqueousFlare (protein leaked from damaged blood vessels)
  • Hypopyon
  • Iris nodules
  • Posterior synechiae
  • Pupil miosis

 

Secondary glaucoma as a complication of Anterior uveitis:

 

  1. Early glaucoma: In the active phase, the inflammatory exudates and cells clog the outflow tract of aqueous humour leading to raised IOP.
  2. Late glaucoma: The pupil block due to seclusio pupillae (ring synechiae) or occlusion pupillae (organized exudates) doesn’t allow aqueous to flow from posterior to the anterior chamber. Peripheral anterior synechiae may be formed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary Open Angle Glaucoma: Typically presents with a gradual loss of peripheral vision over time, not sudden and painful loss of vision. There is also no association with anterior chamber inflammation (cells and flare).

 

Option B. Pseudo exfoliation Glaucoma is associated with the deposition of fibrillar material in the anterior segment and other parts of the eye. It usually does not present with acute symptoms and inflammation like anterior chamber cells and flare.

 

Option C. Phacomorphic Glaucoma caused by a swollen cataractous lens leading to angle closure and elevated IOP. While it can present with a sudden loss of vision and elevated IOP, it does not typically present with anterior uveitis (cells and flare in the anterior chamber).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis with the combination of sudden and painful vision loss, anterior chamber inflammation, fibrin membrane coveing the pupillary area and elevated IOP is Uveitic Glaucoma.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 249

choices.text: Uveitic Glaucoma
Phacomorphic Glaucoma
Pigmentary Glaucoma
Malignant Glaucoma

questions.text: A 52-year-old male came with complaints of severe pain and defective vision in the right eye for the past 2 days. Examination showed Circumcorneal Congestion, Anterior Chamber was shallow, lens showed intumescent Cataract. Intraocular Pressure is 42 mm of Hg. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phacomorphic Glaucoma

 

Option B:

 

  • Phacomorphic glaucoma is the increase in intraocular pressure due to swollen cataractous lens (intumescent cataract)
  • Swollen lens pushes the iris forward & obliterates the angle resulting in secondary acute angle closure glaucoma.

 

Treatment- Control the IOP & removal of cataractous lens.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Uveitic Glaucoma: In an acute attack, signs of anterior uveitis would be present, presents as SOAG. If chronic, seclusion pupillae, iris bombe, peripheral anterior synechiae, scarring of the trabeculum may be present.

 

Option C. Pigmentary Glaucoma: Secondary to Pigment Dispersion syndrome. Secondary pigment dispersion can occur as a consequence of trauma, intraocular tumour and rubbing of a malpositioned IOL on the iris pigment epithelium. Pigment granules from iris pigment epithelium and their deposition throughout the anterior segment is seen.

 

Option D. Malignant Glaucoma: also known as Ciliary block glaucoma, is a rare serious complication of trabeculectomy. It is caused by anterior rotation of the ciliary processes and iris root (ciliolenticular block) leading to a posterior misdirection of aqueous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that the clinical presentation of severe ocular pain, high intraocular pressure, circumcorneal congestion, a shallow anterior chamber, and an intumescent cataract is indicative of Phacomorphic Glaucoma, a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by lens-induced blockage of the anterior chamber angle.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 248

choices.text: Timolol
Latanoprost
Dorzolamide
Brimonidine

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of chronic uveitis presented with raised intraocular pressure. Which of the following drugs is not preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

 

Option B:

 

  • Prostaglandin analogues act by increasing the uveoscleral outflow.
  • These drugs are used as first-line agents in treatment of glaucoma.
  • Anterior uveitis is one of a rare complication, hence it should be used with caution in inflamed eyes.
  • Other ocular side-effects:
    • Conjunctival hyperaemia
    • Eyelash lengthening, thickening, hyperpigmentation
    • Irreversible iris pigmentation
    • Reversible hyperpigmentation of periocular skin
    • Periocular atrophy
    • Increased chances of cystoid macular edema post cataract surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Timolol is a beta-blocker used to lower IOP. It does not typically exacerbate uveitis and can be used unless there are other contraindications (like asthma or heart block). However, systemic absorption of beta-blockers can have cardiovascular and respiratory effects.

 

Option C. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It decreases aqueous humor production and is generally safe in uveitis without specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. While it effectively lowers IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow, brimonidine can have a higher risk of allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost and other prostaglandin analogues, can potentially increase intraocular inflammation or exacerbate pre-existing uveitis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 405

choices.text: 1% Medrysone
0.5% Loteprednol Etabonate
0.1% Fluorometholone
0.1% Dexamethasone

questions.text: Which of the following topical steroid drugs has the high potency for elevating IOP?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.1% Dexamethasone

 

Option D:

 

  • The rates of IOP spikes for various steroids differ and depend on the potency, formulation, and delivery of the particular drug.
  • The rise in IOP may be attribute to deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the TM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1% Medrysone is a relatively weak steroid and has a lower potential for raising IOP compared to more potent steroids.

 

Option B. 0.5% Loteprednol Etabonate is designed to have a lower IOP-elevating potential. It is an ester steroid, which is metabolized into inactive metabolites, reducing the risk of increased IOP.

 

Option C. 0.1% Fluorometholone is also considered to have a lower potential for increasing IOP compared to more potent steroids. It is often chosen for patients who are more susceptible to steroid induced IOP elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IOP rising potency of various topical steroids are as follows:

 

Difluprednate > Dexamethasone > Prednisolone > Fluorometholone > Medrysone

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 402

choices.text: Miosis
Iris Pigmentation
Brow Ache
Accommodative Spasm

questions.text: In a patient using Pilocarpine eye drops, which side effect is not expected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iris Pigmentation

 

Option B:

 

  • In eyes having a narrow angle recess or angle-closure glaucoma, constriction of the pupil pulls the peripheral iris away from the angle structures, opening a functionally closed angle.
  • It is commonly used as 2–4% drops 6–8 hourly.
  • Side effects: Miosis, Brow Ache and accommodative Spasm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Miosis, or constriction of the pupil, is a direct effect of pilocarpine. By stimulating muscarinic receptors in the iris sphincter muscle, pilocarpine causes the pupils to constrict. This is an expected side effect.

 

Option C. Brow ache or headache is a common side effect of pilocarpine. This occurs due to the contraction of the ciliary muscle and the muscles of the iris, which can cause discomfort around the eyes and forehead.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine can cause accommodative spasm, which is an involuntary contraction of the ciliary muscle leading to excessive focusing ability of the eye for near vision. This can result in blurred vision for distance and eye strain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist, commonly causes miosis, brow ache, and accommodative spasm as side effects due to its mechanism of action, it does not cause increased iris pigmentation, which is more typical of prostaglandin analogues.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 156
